Outline

Intro

  • Romans so far: The Man (1:1–7), The Heart (1:8–15), now The Message (1:16–32)

  • Two powerful revelations:

    • Good News: God's righteousness revealed (16–17)

    • Bad News: God's wrath revealed (18–32)

  • Big idea: Only at the cross do righteousness and wrath perfectly meet.

I. The Gospel Revealed: A Righteousness We Could Never Earn (16–17)

  • Paul’s passion: Unashamed confidence in the gospel

  • Gospel = God’s power (δύναμις [dynamis]—"dynamite") that rescues and transforms

  • Righteousness revealed as a gift (status given, not standard earned)

  • Received and sustained by faith alone—from justification to glorification

  • Gospel’s power = Holy Spirit working through proclamation

    • Convicts, convinces, reveals Father's love, regenerates hearts

ILLUSTRATION:

  • President pardoning death-row inmate and taking his place—exactly what Jesus did for us.

APPLICATION:

  • Stop striving, receive righteousness by grace through faith

  • Rest in God’s acceptance through the Spirit’s power

II. The Wrath Revealed: A Rebellion We All Participate In (18–23)

  • Wrath = God’s holy justice confronting evil

  • Root issue: Truth suppression, not ignorance

  • Natural Theology: God plainly reveals Himself

    • Cosmological, Teleological, Moral arguments point to God's existence

  • Idolatry: exchanging Creator for created things, glory for garbage

  • Result: Darkened minds, foolish hearts

ILLUSTRATION:

  • Conscience ("with knowledge"): Our inner witness to God’s law we seek to silence.

APPLICATION:

  • Stop running from conscience; it’s God calling you home

  • Embrace discomfort, repent, let conviction lead to freedom

  • Cultivate sensitivity to the Spirit—turn guilt into gratitude

III. The Judgment Displayed: A Culture Unraveling Itself (24–31)

  • "God gave them up": Passive yet intentional judgment

  • Downward Spiral:

    • Sexual impurity → dishonorable passions → debased mind

  • Same-sex behavior illustrates rebellion against natural design

  • Societal sins (envy, murder, arrogance, etc.): symptoms of deeper collapse

  • Losing God = losing morality and civilization itself

ILLUSTRATION:

  • Days of Noah: judgment delayed, sin embraced, sudden ruin.

APPLICATION:

  • Recognize cultural warning signs; don't ignore spiritual alarms

  • Resist spiritual numbness—respond with gospel urgency

  • Be a prophetic voice speaking truth compassionately, clearly, courageously

IV. The Verdict Announced: A World That Celebrates What God Condemns (32)

  • Final stage of collapse: Celebrating and applauding sin

  • Sin becomes art, depravity becomes policy, rebellion becomes identity

  • Paul's verdict: "You have no excuse" (Chapter 2)—everyone needs grace

ILLUSTRATION:

  • Judge applauding criminals—symbolizing moral insanity and rebellion against God

APPLICATION:

  • Love people fiercely; reject evil relentlessly

  • Guard your heart—grieve what grieves God

  • Stand courageously; speak truth lovingly even when unpopular

Conclusion: The Message That Still Saves

  • Romans 1 necessary to see clearly: prepares us for gospel beauty

  • Gospel summary: Wrath poured on Jesus, righteousness credited to us

  • At the cross: mercy triumphs, sinners embraced, lives transformed

FINAL APPEAL:

  • If lost: Run to Jesus; mercy awaits

  • If weary of striving: Rest in Christ’s righteousness by faith

  • If pressured to compromise truth: Remember, only the true gospel saves

Paul declared boldly:
"I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation..."

  • Make this message your passion

  • Proclaim boldly, stand courageously, live joyfully—never ashamed

Apostle Paul: The Message of a Missionary

Romans 1:16–32

Introduction

If Romans 1:1–7 showed us the man, and Romans 1:8–15 showed us his heart, then Romans 1:16–32 shows us his message. And it’s not vague or soft. It’s piercing. It cuts through culture, religion, philosophy, and personal morality like a double-edged sword.

This section of Romans gives us two powerful revelations that define Paul’s entire theology: the righteousness of God revealed in the gospel, and the wrath of God revealed against human sin. One saves. The other condemns. And the only safe place to stand is under the cross of Christ, where wrath and righteousness meet.

Let’s walk the text, and let the message of the missionary grip us.

I. The Gospel Revealed: A Righteousness We Could Never Earn (16–17)

Paul doesn’t begin this section of Romans with warnings—but with worship. With boldness. With gospel confidence.

“I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes...” (16)

That’s not just a slogan. It’s Paul’s driving passion and divine manifesto. After expressing his eagerness and holy obligation to preach (vv. 14–15), Paul now tells us why he’s unashamed. Because the gospel is not man’s strategy. It’s God’s power.

The Greek word for “power” is δύναμις [dynamis] – the root of our word “dynamite.” Paul’s saying the gospel is not just informative—it’s explosive. It raises the spiritually dead. It demolishes strongholds. It rescues sinners. And it’s for everyone who believes.

Paul then explains how it works:

"In it, the righteousness of God is revealed from faith for faith..."

This phrase is theological dynamite. It means:

  • God’s own righteousness is put on display.

  • That righteousness is not a standard we climb to, but a status God grants.

  • It’s received by faith, not earned by works.

Paul quotes Habakkuk 2:4: “The righteous shall live by faith.” In other words, the whole Christian life—from justification to glorification—is sustained by faith.

And how exactly is this gospel powerful? It’s not some magic incantation. No, God has chosen to unleash this power through ordinary people preaching His extraordinary message, empowered by the Holy Spirit. As we proclaim Christ crucified and risen, the Spirit moves powerfully:

  • He convicts us of sin and our desperate need for a Savior.

  • He convinces our hearts of the truth and beauty of Christ.

  • He reveals the Father's and acceptance, pouring divine love into estranged hearts.

  • He regenerates spiritually dead souls, causing us to be born again by the power of His Spirit

That’s why the gospel isn’t mere words—it’s divinely empowered proclamation of the Good News!

Illustration:

Imagine a man on death row for murder. The day of execution comes. He hears the guards’ boots approaching, heart pounding. But instead of the executioner, the door opens, and in walks the President of the United States. Only he has the authority to pardon. He says, “I long to show mercy. I want to sign your pardon.” But outside the prison, the victim’s family holds signs: We demand justice.

The President says, “If I sign this, mercy wins—but justice is robbed. If I refuse, justice is served—but mercy is silent. But I know how both can be satisfied.”

He signs the pardon, hands it to the warden, and says, “Let him go free. Expunge his record.” Then the President straps himself into the electric chair and says, “Only I have the authority to take his place.” And then he says: “Warden, pull the switch.”

Would the President do that for you? No. Neither do I. But that’s exactly what Jesus Christ, the God-Man, has done.

Application:

  • Stop striving to earn what God has already given.

  • Walk in the warm sunshine of God’s acceptance.

  • Receive the gift of righteousness—by grace, through faith from the Spirit’s power.

Transition:

But the good news is only good because the bad news is true. Righteousness only matters if we're unrighteous. Grace only amazes when judgment is real. Before Paul explains how the gospel saves, he shows us why we need saving in the first place. If we don’t understand the wrath, we’ll never truly see are need for infinite mercy and a savior.

II. The Wrath Revealed: A Rebellion We All Participate In (18–23)

“For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who by their unrighteousness suppress the truth.” (18)

This isn’t petty anger or divine overreaction. This is holy justice. Wrath is what happens when a good God confronts evil.

And what provokes it? Suppression of truth. Not ignorance—rebellion. People know God exists. Creation screams it. Conscience whispers it. But they press it down.

“For what can be known about God is plain to them, because God has shown it to them.” (19)

Paul isn't speaking theoretically—he’s speaking about reality itself. He's introducing us to what theologians call natural theology, the idea that God's existence and attributes are evident through creation itself. Even before opening the Bible, we can recognize God's fingerprints in the world around us. Consider three classic apologetic arguments briefly:

  • The Cosmological Argument: Every effect has a cause. The universe exists—therefore, it must have a cause that is timeless, powerful, and personal: God.

  • The Teleological (Design) Argument: The universe isn't chaotic; it's finely tuned and ordered. Complexity and purpose imply an intelligent Designer behind it all: God.

  • The Moral Argument: We instinctively know some things are right and others are wrong. Objective morality points to an ultimate moral lawgiver: God.

In other words, God has left unmistakable clues about Himself everywhere. Creation proclaims His glory. Our conscience bears witness to His holiness. Yet humanity suppresses this truth in rebellion.

  • They know God but refuse to glorify Him.

  • They exchange God for idols.

  • They become darkened in their thinking and foolish in their hearts.

This is the root of all sin: idolatry. Replacing the Creator with created things. Replacing glory with garbage.

Illustration:

We’re created in the image of God—free moral agents uniquely endowed with a conscience. This is what separates humanity from animals. While biologically similar, spiritually we are profoundly different. The word conscience itself reveals this: con- meaning "with," and -science meaning "knowledge." Every time we sin, we break God’s inner law with knowledge. Our conscience testifies against us, and deep down we know it. Yet we desperately seek ways to silence that voice—through drugs, sex, distractions, success, adrenaline—anything to drown out the echo of eternity stamped within our souls.

Application:

  • Stop running from the whisper of eternity.
    Your conscience isn't just guilt or moral pressure—it's the voice of God calling you back to Himself. Every pang of conscience is an invitation from your Creator to return home.

  • Embrace the discomfort.
    Instead of numbing your conscience through distraction, entertainment, or pleasure, let its discomfort guide you toward repentance, healing, and real freedom.

  • Cultivate sensitivity to the Spirit.
    Don’t silence the very mechanism God gave you to lead you to joy. Ask the Holy Spirit to restore and sharpen your conscience, turning guilt into gratitude, and regret into worship.

Transition:

When you exchange God, you don’t remain neutral—you spiral downward. Suppressing your conscience doesn't just affect you personally—it infects the culture around you. Idolatry distorts minds, corrupts desires, and erodes societies from the inside out. And here’s how God’s wrath becomes visible: not in lightning bolts, but in letting humanity have exactly what it desires apart from Him. He withdraws His restraining grace. He gives people over to themselves—and the result is judgment unfolding before our very eyes.

III. The Judgment Displayed: A Culture Unraveling Itself (24–31)

“God gave them up...” (24, 26, 28)

This repeated phrase is chilling. God’s judgment here isn’t thunderous fury—it’s sobering silence. He removes His restraining grace and allows humanity to plunge headlong into the consequences of its rebellion. This divine withdrawal isn’t passive indifference; it’s intentional judgment.

Notice the spiral downward clearly laid out by Paul:

  • Sexual impurity (24)
    God-given boundaries for intimacy dissolve, and what was once sacred becomes profane.

  • Dishonorable passions (26–27)
    Paul specifically highlights same-sex relationships—not because they’re uniquely sinful, but because they vividly demonstrate how human rebellion overturns not just God's commands, but the very created order itself. Nature itself is inverted.

  • A debased mind (28–31)
    This final stage is societal chaos—a mind no longer capable of discerning good from evil. Morality becomes fluid, virtue becomes mocked, and wickedness becomes normalized.

Paul doesn’t limit judgment to individual sins; he shows a cascade of societal collapse: envy, murder, arrogance, brutality, deceit, slander, hatred of God, disobedience to parents. This isn’t random—it's symptomatic. When you lose God, you lose the very foundation on which human dignity, morality, and civilization rest.

Illustration:

Remember the days of Noah. People mocked, partied, and ignored the warnings. God didn’t strike immediately—He simply gave them over to their desires. They felt free, unrestrained, liberated from judgment—right up until the day judgment fell. When God withdraws His restraining hand, we don’t find freedom; we find ruin.

Application:

  • Don’t ignore the warning lights.
    Look at our culture honestly—are we seeing these signs today? We don't just see sin; we see sin celebrated, normalized, and institutionalized.

  • Resist spiritual numbness.
    Don’t become indifferent to the moral chaos around you. See it clearly, grieve it deeply, and let it compel you toward mission. Our culture’s pain is a call for God's people to hold fast and proclaim His rescue boldly.

  • Be a prophetic voice, not a passive spectator.
    Speak the truth with humility, clarity, and urgency—not out of condemnation, but from compassion for a culture unraveling before our eyes.

Transition:

Yet Paul takes us even deeper. He shows us that the most frightening symptom of a collapsing culture isn’t merely people sinning—it’s people actively celebrating and championing sin. When wickedness moves from rebellion to entertainment, from vice to virtue, and from shame to identity, we’re no longer merely seeing rebellion—we’re witnessing its enthronement.

IV. The Verdict Announced: A World That Celebrates What God Condemns (32)

“Though they know God's righteous decree... they not only do them but give approval to those who practice them.”

This is the final, tragic stage of cultural collapse—not merely sinning, but celebrating sin. When a society reaches this point, evil no longer hides—it parades proudly through the streets.

  • Sin becomes art.
    Immorality and darkness become entertainment, the new normal, and even beauty is twisted to reflect our depravity.

  • Depravity becomes policy.
    Law, which should restrain evil, instead begins to sanction, institutionalize, and protect it.

  • Rebellion becomes identity.
    What should produce shame now produces pride. Sin isn’t just practiced—it’s claimed as our deepest identity, leaving no room for repentance or rescue.

But Paul is careful to remind us—this isn’t just a problem "out there." In the next breath, he'll say clearly in chapter 2: "You have no excuse." It doesn't matter whether you're Jew or Gentile, religious or secular, morally upright or openly rebellious. Apart from Christ, we all stand condemned and desperately need grace.

Illustration:

Imagine a courtroom where the judge not only dismisses the charges against criminals but invites applause, honors them publicly, and condemns those who speak up for justice. When a culture openly approves, applauds, and celebrates what God condemns, it’s effectively shaking its fist at heaven itself.

Application:

  • Love people fiercely, but reject evil relentlessly.
    You can't genuinely love sinners by celebrating the sin destroying them. Compassion speaks the truth, even when the culture demands silence or applause.

  • Guard your heart carefully.
    Refuse to laugh at things that grieve God. Discernment means more than knowing right from wrong—it means grieving what grieves the heart of God.

  • Stand courageously, even if you stand alone.
    Resist cultural pressure to approve or participate in what Christ died to forgive. Let your life be a clear and compassionate testimony: truth spoken in love, conviction tempered with humility.

Transition:

Now you understand why Paul felt such urgency, such unwavering boldness about the gospel. It's not just another religious message. It's the only power capable of rescuing people from the spiral of sin and restoring us to a holy God.

Conclusion: The Message That Still Saves

Romans 1 is not popular—but it's deeply necessary. It shows us the unfiltered truth about the world and about ourselves. But it doesn't leave us in despair; it prepares us to behold the breathtaking beauty of Christ and the unmatched glory of the gospel.

Here is the astonishing good news we must never forget:

“But God shows his love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.” (Romans 5:8)

At the cross, something unimaginable happened:

  • The wrath we deserved was fully and finally poured out—not on us—but on Jesus.

  • The righteousness we desperately need but could never earn was freely credited—not by our goodness—but by His grace alone.

Jesus willingly took the condemnation so that we could freely receive mercy. He bore our shame so that we could know acceptance. He experienced abandonment so that we could be embraced forever by the Father.

This gospel—Paul’s driving passion and divine manifesto—is not only true; it's beautifully good. It still rescues the broken. It still restores sinners. It still transforms lives.

Final Appeal:

  • If you feel the weight of guilt and know you’re under wrath—run to Jesus. His arms are open wide, offering forgiveness and cleansing.

  • If you’re exhausted from trying to earn what God freely gives—rest today in Christ's finished work. Receive His perfect righteousness by simple faith.

  • If the pressure of our culture tempts you to soften the truth—stand firm. Remember, only the true, unaltered gospel has power to save and restore.

Paul declared boldly:

“I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation...”

This was his life-defining message. Make it yours today. Proclaim it confidently. Stand in it courageously. Live it joyfully. And, by God’s grace, never be ashamed.
